awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Bidirectional Control of Sleep and Wakefulness by the Hypothalamic Arcuate Nucleus
awd_abstract_narration:
Despite the fact that sleep is universal across the animal kingdom and occupies a substantial portion of an animal's lifetime, the regulation of sleep and wakefulness by the brain is poorly understood.  Additionally, national surveys show that sleep is poorly understood among the general public and that many Americans, particularly students, are extremely sleep deprived.  Therefore, this project integrates a series of research and educational goals to impact our understanding of the brain mechanisms that control mammalian sleep.  The PI will manipulate two populations of neurons (called AgRP neurons and POMC neurons) in rodent brains using powerful genetic technologies to determine their roles in regulating sleep/wake behavior.  These groups of neurons are well-known for sensing the nutritional and caloric needs of the body, and so our research will study how food intake affects states of sleep and wakefulness. This work will thus increase our understanding of how the brain coordinates complex behavioral states, in this case hunger and sleep.  The educational goals will broaden the impact of this project by including undergraduates in all aspects of this research and by implementing a new course at Williams College on the science of sleep.  This course will produce educational materials on sleep that will be freely available and distributed. Together, the research and educational components of this award will increase the United States' competitiveness in science and technology, particularly in the field of neuroscience.  

The goal of this project is to determine how neurons that regulate energy homeostasis also regulate sleep.  Previous studies indicate that sleep/wake states are significantly affected by food need and availability, but the role of neurons that regulate food intake in sleep/wake behavior is unknown.  The hypothalamic arcuate nucleus contains two populations of neurons that regulate food intake behavior: orexigenic agouti-related protein (AgRP)-expressing neurons and anorexigenic pro-opiomelanocortin (POMC)-expressing neurons.  Preliminary evidence from our laboratory suggests that AgRP neurons can independently promote wakefulness and food intake and that POMC neurons maintain sleep states in addition to suppressing appetite.  Previous data also suggest that AgRP and POMC neurons might influence sleep/wake states by projecting to hypocretin-expressing neurons and melanin-concentrating hormone-expressing neurons, respectively, in the lateral hypothalamus.  This project will use cutting-edge optogenetic and chemogenetic methods in combination with electroencephalography (EEG) and behavioral analyses to increase our understanding of these systems in sleep/wake behavior and thus how the brain coordinates complex behavioral states. Undergraduate students will be involved in all aspects of this work, which will further impact the field of neuroscience through the hands-on training it will provide for the next generation of scientists and educators.

por.por_cntn:
This project has integrated a series of research and educational goals to impact the understanding of mammalian sleep. 

The goal of our research was to study the interaction between states of hunger and states of sleep using mice as a model organism. Because it is impossible to eat and sleep at the same time, we hypothesized that neurons in the brain that regulate hunger are also likely to affect the quantity and quality of sleep. We focused on two populations of neurons in the brain that are well-known to regulate hunger: activity in a group of neurons called “AgRP neurons” cause an animal to become motivated to seek food; in contrast, activity in a group of neurons called “POMC neurons” cause an animal to feel satiated and to cease food consumption. We hypothesized that when AgRP neurons are active or stimulated, an animal would show decreased sleep quantity and quality, while when POMC neurons are active or stimulated, an animal would show increased sleep quantity and quality. 

Sleep quantity and quality can be measured using a technique called electroencephalography (EEG). By implanting EEG devices in mice, we can discriminate between states of wakefulness and two states of sleep: non-rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep, and rapid eye movement (REM) sleep. 

In initial experiments, we first asked how sleep quantity was affected in food-deprived mice versus mice with access to food. We found that food deprivation decreased the total amount of time mice spent in NREM sleep and increased the total time they were awake. When looking at properties of the EEG signal during NREM sleep, we found that the quality of the sleep was also decreased. For example, the number of “micro-awakenings,” brief changes in the EEG that last less than 5 seconds but cause a brief awakening-like event, increased when mice were food deprived compared to when they had full access to food. 

Because food deprivation causes activation of AgRP neurons, we studied the effects of artificial AgRP neuron activation on sleep quantity and quality. Stimulating AgRP using a method called optogenetics caused decreases in NREM sleep quantity and quality that was strikingly similar to the effects of food deprivation. To test whether AgRP neuron activity was necessary for the effects of food deprivation on sleep, we food deprived animals while inhibiting AgRP neurons. Decreasing activity in AgRP neurons decreased the effect of food deprivation on sleep, demonstrating that those effects are at least partially mediated by activity in AgRP neurons. Finally, we tested the hypothesis that activity in POMC neurons would increase sleep quantity and quality. We found that artificially stimulating POMC neurons had no effect on sleep in mice with constant access to food, however, POMC neuron stimulation rescued the effects on sleep caused by food deprivation. Taken together, these experiments show that the relative balance of activity in AgRP and POMC neurons can affect states of sleep and wakefulness.

In recent experiments, we have studied how sleep deprivation affects activity in AgRP neurons. We hypothesized that when an animal transitions from NREM sleep to wake, activity in AgRP neurons decreases, presumably so the animal can commit to a sleep state. Using a technique called fiber photometry, we measured activity in AgRP neurons during different sleep state transitions. Indeed, we found that AgRP neuron activity decreases during transitions from wake to NREM sleep, and then increases again once an animal wakes from sleep. 

Taken together, these research studies have shown that the neurons that regulate the homeostatic drive to seek food can modulate sleep behavior, and the need for sleep can, in turn, modulate activity in these neurons. Future directions will study the exact circuits involved in these behaviors and determine the source of input from neural populations that promote sleep onto AgRP neurons.           

The educational goals of this projected broadened the impact of this project by including undergraduates in all aspects of this research. Over the history of this project, over 30 undergraduates received training in all aspects of scientific research including study design, performing experiments, data analysis, data visualization, and publication of manuscripts. These students are now in prominent graduate PhD programs, MD programs, and in biotech fields. Additionally, this project allowed the Primary Investigator, Matt Carter, to design a new course on sleep at Williams College, “The Science of Sleep.” 60 undergraduate students took offerings of this course, and the PI was invited to give regular talks on sleep science to students at Williams and other institutions.
